DOCNAME: CASE OF VAN DER TANG v. SPAIN
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection rejected (ex delicto non oritur actio);No violation of Art. 5-3
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG Mr PERSON was born in DATE and lives in GPE in the GPE . At the material time he worked as a lorry driver .

CARDINAL . ORG In TIME of CARDINAL DATE Mr PERSON was arrested by the police ( ORG ) in GPE , GPE , on the north - west coast of GPE . He was found driving a lorry which contained QUANTITY of hashish . The lorry belonged to the applicant . He was also found in possession of a pistol with its serial number chiselled off and of a radio pre - tuned to a station which coincided with that of another set found later in the possession of PERSON , who was also arrested ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL more people were subsequently detained for allegedly being involved in a CARDINAL - stage operation to deliver QUANTITY of hashish .

CARDINAL . ORG According to the applicant 's statement to the police , made with the assistance of a lawyer and an interpreter on CARDINAL DATE , an unknown person had approached him sometime in DATE and again in DATE and offered him MONEY to transport QUANTITY of " dope " ( droga ) from PERSON to the GPE . After some hesitation PERSON had finally accepted . Late in the TIME of CARDINAL DATE , following the unknown person 's instructions , he had taken his truck to PERSON , where another man had loaded the drugs and then gone away . The applicant had only been driving for TIME when he was arrested .

This statement was confirmed by the applicant on CARDINAL DATE before the relevant judicial authority ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , PERSON investigating judge no . CARDINAL , who then ordered PERSON detention pending trial ( auto de prisión ) . Basing his decision on sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure ( Ley de Enjuiciamiento Criminal , " LECrim " - see paragraphs DATE and CARDINAL below ) , the judge held that there was sufficient reason to believe that the applicant was criminally responsible for the commission of a public - health offence . According to the applicant , the other persons detained , all NORP nationals , were unconditionally released .

On DATE Mr PERSON made a written statement to ORG investigating judge no . CARDINAL in which he explained that , contrary to his previous statements , he had not known that he was transporting drugs at the time of his arrest . He had thought the consignment was tobacco but had said drugs because of the pressure put on him and language difficulties .

CARDINAL . ORG In an order of CARDINAL DATE ( auto de procesamiento ) investigating judge no . CARDINAL decided that the available evidence was sufficient to charge the applicant with an offence against public health ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL bis ( a ) of LAW - see paragraphs DATE and CARDINAL below ) and unlawful possession of a firearm ( section CARDINAL of LAW - see paragraph DATE below ) . The applicant 's detention was confirmed . An appeal by the applicant against this order appears to have been dismissed .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE and CARDINAL DATE Mr PERSON lodged with investigating judge no . CARDINAL his first applications for provisional release . Arguing that he had throughout been unaware of the real nature of the consignment , he insisted that he was not involved with any drug - trafficking organisation . He further complained that during his DATE detention he had only been questioned twice by the judge - in DATE and DATE - and was the only person still held in custody despite the relatively minor character of his offence . PERSON also undertook to comply with any conditions attached to his release .
These applications were rejected on DATE and DATE respectively by means of orders not containing reasons .

CARDINAL . ORG A similar application for provisional release followed on DATE and was rejected on DATE by an auto ( reasoned decision ) . The ground for the decision was the seriousness of the offences - illegal possession of a firearm and drug trafficking in large quantities ; the second offence in itself attracting a prison sentence of " prisión menor en su grado medio " ( that is , from DATE , DATE and DATE to DATE and DATE ) .
CARDINAL . ORG By an order of DATE ( auto PERSON del sumario ) the applicant was committed for trial .

CARDINAL . ORG Further applications for provisional release were addressed to FAC in GPE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) on DATE , CARDINAL May , DATE and CARDINAL DATE . On DATE the GPE public prosecutor ( Ministerio Fiscal ) stated that he would not oppose the applicant 's release provided that he paid security of MONEY , handed in his passport and reported DATE to the police . However , on DATE the ORG refused the applications for release , briefly stating : " The original circumstances on which the detention pending trial was decided remain unchanged " ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The applicant then requested ORG to reconsider its decision , complaining , inter alia , that several co - detainees in respect of whom the prosecution was seeking sentences of DATE ten years ' imprisonment had obtained conditional release upon payment of MONEY . In the applicant 's submission , only the fact of his being a foreigner seemed to account for his long period of detention . On DATE the ORG declined to reconsider its decision .

CARDINAL . ORG In the course of DATE the NORP authorities had launched a nationwide operation ( Operación Nécora ) to combat a large - scale drug - trafficking organisation which operated mainly in GPE . Central investigating judge no . CARDINAL in FAC , GPE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , was put in charge of the overall investigation .

The applicant 's case was considered to be closely linked with other files relating to ORG and was therefore transferred to GPE on DATE . ORG had heard the parties beforehand ; the applicant 's lawyer did not make any submissions ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE central investigating judge no . CARDINAL issued an order ( auto de procesamiento ) whereby new charges were added against the applicant without any alteration to the established facts . He was now charged not only with an offence against public health and unlawful possession of a firearm of foreign origin ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) but also with smuggling and criminal association ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) . An appeal by the applicant against these orders which included a request for release was eventually rejected on DATE by ORG of the Audiencia Nacional . The grounds for the decision not to release the applicant were the seriousness of the alleged offences , considerations of public order and the high risk of absconding on account of the applicant 's foreign nationality .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant had lodged a fresh application for release with investigating judge no . CARDINAL in which he repeated arguments adduced earlier and additionally submitted that the transfer of his case to GPE would inevitably mean that his trial would be further delayed . The public prosecutor opposed the applicant 's release , and on DATE central investigating judge no . CARDINAL decided to continue the applicant 's detention in view of the available evidence , the nature of the offence and its seriousness , the prison sentence that it would attract , the extent of the applicant 's involvement and the likelihood of his absconding .

PERSON challenged this in ORG of the Audiencia Nacional . In his appeal the applicant submitted , inter alia , that as his alleged offence was wholly unconnected with the charges relating to drug trafficking , he could easily have been tried DATE after his arrest . He further submitted that , in any case , even if he were to be found guilty of the offences with which he was charged , he would already have served his sentence in detention pending trial ( over DATE ) . On DATE the Audiencia Nacional dismissed the appeal , thereby confirming the investigating judge 's decision .

The applicant 's subsequent constitutional complaint ( recurso de amparo ) was declared inadmissible by ORG on DATE on the ground that none of the issues raised by the applicant were of a constitutional nature .

CARDINAL . ORG In the meantime , in a telegram of CARDINAL DATE addressed to central investigating judge no . CARDINAL , the applicant had renewed his application for release . The public prosecutor attached to the Audiencia Nacional requested that the applicant 's detention be prolonged to the statutory maximum of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . PERSON responded by offering to make a formal undertaking that he would reside in PERSON should his release be granted . On DATE central investigating judge no . CARDINAL decided to continue the applicant 's detention and to adjourn any decision on the public prosecutor 's request for its extension .

CARDINAL . ORG As PERSON period of detention approached DATE , the central investigating judge no . CARDINAL decided on CARDINAL DATE , in accordance with LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and after hearing the parties , that the maximum duration of the detention should be extended by DATE . He based this decision on the seriousness of the charges and the sentence which could be imposed in the event of conviction .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the central investigating judge no . CARDINAL concluded the preliminary investigation . The case was sent to ORG of the Audiencia Nacional for trial .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant lodged a new application for release , this time with the Audiencia Nacional , which on DATE allowed it subject to the following conditions : ( a ) the applicant was to pay in cash a security of MONEY ; ( b ) he was to give an address and inform the court of any subsequent change ; ( c ) he was to report DATE to the police in GPE ; and ( d ) he was not to leave NORP territory .
The Audiencia Nacional gave the following reasons for its decision :

" There is prima - facie evidence that ... the accused did not play a major role in any of the organisations concerned , as he merely transported the illegal substance in question , the nature of which also has to be taken into account by the court .

The time that has elapsed since PERSON was placed in custody - over DATE ( he has been in detention far longer than any of the other defendants in this case ) - means that it is possible to rule out his being able to conceal or suppress evidence .

The period of time that has elapsed clearly - why not be frank about it ? - owes much to ill fortune and the vicissitudes of the proceedings . He could have been tried in GPE DATE , when the GPE public prosecutor did not oppose his provisional release .

The same lapse of time , viewed in the context of the brief provisional summary of the facts , argues in favour of varying the order placing him in detention pending trial , relaxing the conditions of detention by making it possible to avoid it altogether , provided that the measures referred to in the operative provisions below are taken so as to ensure that he appears for trial .

The court did not consider that the accused 's foreign nationality constituted an insurmountable obstacle to reaching this conclusion , because other foreign defendants in the case are in fact not being held in detention . The court simply took the view that it was just another factor which , combined with the accused 's lack of close ties with GPE , could lend support to the idea that he might be likely to seek to evade trial ; but that can not be presumed without additional evidence . Furthermore , this type of fear , which is always relative , can not in such circumstances have the effect of inexorably making the accused serve in advance the sentence which may be imposed on him . This is particularly so as the accused has shown , at least to some extent , that he is able to remain on NORP territory and obtain a contract of employment there which would enable him to engage in a lawful activity for the duration of the contract . "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , in response to a request by the applicant for a reduction in the amount of the security , the Audiencia Nacional set it at MONEY either to be paid in cash or to be guaranteed by a bank . On DATE the security was deposited by the applicant 's wife , whereupon Mr PERSON was released .
CARDINAL . ORG During his stay in ORG prison , PERSON was of good behaviour and participated in several prison activities . He also worked as a clerk in the prison bursar 's office .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , on an application by PERSON , the Audiencia Nacional gave him leave to report to the police only once a week and returned certain documents to him , including his driving licence .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant sought permission to travel to the GPE in order to spend DATE with his family . This request was refused by the Audiencia Nacional on DATE in view of the obvious risk of absconding .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant travelled by car from GPE to the GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG By letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant 's GPE lawyer informed his NORP lawyers that their client had left GPE and returned to the GPE , as he had no means of subsistence . The GPE lawyer requested them to secure a variation of the conditions on which release had been granted , in particular the obligation to stay in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG In a letter of DATE to the NORP embassy in GPE , the GPE lawyer proposed that PERSON should report DATE to the embassy . He further stated that his client intended to return to GPE in order to stand trial . The embassy answered by advising the applicant to contact the Audiencia Nacional .
Neither the applicant nor his representatives appear to have contacted the Audiencia Nacional at this stage , nor do they seem to have informed that court of his new address .

CARDINAL . ORG Meanwhile , on DATE , the Audiencia Nacional had confirmed the investigating judge 's decision to conclude the investigation ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , thereby ordering the opening of the trial ( juicio oral ) . By that time the case file ran to CARDINAL pages . On DATE the public prosecutor made provisional indictment submissions ( conclusiones provisionales ) containing charges against CARDINAL people . In respect of the applicant , the public prosecutor demanded a total prison sentence of DATE and a fine of MONEY in respect of an offence against public health ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) and of unlawful possession of a firearm of foreign origin ( see paragraphs DATE and CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . ORG In a summons of DATE the applicant was ordered to appear before the trial court . However , the summons could not be served on him , as he no longer lived at the address he had originally given the NORP authorities .

On DATE the police informed the court that the applicant 's whereabouts were unknown . Thereupon the Audiencia Nacional ordered the applicant and his surety - his wife - to appear before it on DATE at a hearing concerning the forfeiture of the bail .

The applicant 's NORP lawyer filed an objection against this order , submitting , inter alia , that the applicant had had to leave GPE for a compelling reason , namely the terminal illness of his father , but that he had no intention of evading NORP justice and would appear for trial . On DATE the Audiencia Nacional , noting that the applicant had failed to comply with the conditions attached to his release , dismissed the objection and ordered his arrest .
On DATE the Audiencia Nacional declared that the applicant had failed to appear ( rebeldía ) and his security was forfeited .
CARDINAL . ORG The trial took place in GPE from DATE to CARDINAL DATE . PERSON did not attend it and could therefore not be tried pursuant to CARDINAL of LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the Audiencia Nacional delivered a CARDINAL-page - long judgment . PERSON ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) was held to have played a leading role in importing very large quantities of hashish . He was accordingly sentenced to a total of DATE imprisonment and a fine of MONEY . It does not appear from the facts set out in this judgment that the applicant was involved in drug - trafficking activities beyond the transporting of QUANTITY of hashish for which he was arrested ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . ORG The NORP authorities have not requested PERSON extradition .

CARDINAL . ORG In ordinary cases the investigation of all types of offence falls to the investigating judge ( juez de instrucción ) in whose district the offence has been committed ( FAC LECrim ) . Upon completion of the investigation , the investigating judge may , by means of an order ( auto PERSON del sumario y apertura del juicio oral - section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) LECrim ) commit the accused for trial at FAC in whose province the offence in question has been committed ( section CARDINAL.IV LECrim ) .

CARDINAL . Offences concerning drug trafficking that have been committed by " organised gangs or groups and affect various provinces " and any other connected offences come within the jurisdiction of the Audiencia Nacional in GPE ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( e ) and in fine of FAC , " LOPJ " ) . In such cases investigation falls to the relevant central investigating judge ( juez de instrucción central ) attached to FAC , likewise in GPE ( section CARDINAL LOPJ ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Where the same facts are being examined by CARDINAL courts , the one which considers that it has jurisdiction must ask the other to transfer the file to it ( inhibitoria ) . In such cases the decision to transfer the file can only be taken after the parties have been heard ( section CARDINAL LOPJ ) and is always final , no appeal being possible ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW , " anyone who cultivates , manufactures or traffics in toxic or stupefying drugs or psychotropic substances or in any other way promotes , encourages or facilitates the unlawful consumption of them , or possesses them for such purposes " , shall be liable to a term of imprisonment ranging from DATE and DATE to DATE and DATE ( de arresto mayor en su grado máximo a prisión menor en su grado medio ) and to a fine of QUANTITY , provided that the damage to health caused by the substances or products involved is not serious . PERSON is regarded as such a substance , as opposed to " hard drugs " .
CARDINAL . ORG However , under LAW , the relevant term of imprisonment is substantially increased , ranging from DATE , DATE and DATE to DATE , where :
" CARDINAL . ... the quantity of toxic or stupefying drugs or psychotropic substances ... is particularly large .
CARDINAL . ORG ... the offender belongs to an organisation , even a provisional one , that could have the aim of spreading such substances or products even on an occasional basis . "
CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW of LAW , the unlawful possession of a firearm , without the required licence , is punishable with imprisonment ranging from DATE , DATE and DATE to DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG The term of imprisonment ranges from DATE and DATE to DATE where the firearms are of foreign origin and have been brought into NORP territory illegally ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG LAW secures the right to liberty and security of person and sets out the conditions under which a person 's liberty may be restricted . By paragraph CARDINAL of this provision , a habeas corpus procedure shall be provided for by law , which shall also determine the maximum duration of detention pending trial .
CARDINAL . ORG Under section CARDINAL LECrim :
" The following conditions must be satisfied for pre - trial detention to be ordered :
CARDINAL . ORG The commission of an act which may constitute an offence ( delito ) must have been established .

CARDINAL . ORG The offence must be punishable by DATE imprisonment ( prisión menor ) or , if the term of imprisonment is shorter , the judge must consider it necessary to remand the accused in custody in the light of his criminal record , the circumstances of the offence , the disturbance of public order it has caused or the frequency with which similar acts have been committed ...
CARDINAL . ORG There must be sufficient reasons to consider the person to be remanded in custody criminally responsible for the offence . "

CARDINAL . ORG According to LAW , detention pending trial shall not exceed DATE where an offence is punishable with a term of imprisonment ranging from DATE and DATE to DATE ( prisión menor ) and shall not exceed DATE if the applicable sentence is more severe .

CARDINAL . ORG If , however , owing to certain circumstances the case can not be tried within that period and there is a risk that the accused may evade justice , LAW provides that detention pending trial may be prolonged up to DATE respectively . A reasoned decision ( auto ) to this effect shall only be issued after the competent court has heard the accused and the public prosecutor .
CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW ( CARDINAL ) LECrim detention pending trial may last only as long as the original reasons remain valid .
